title: China Eximbank restructures 1997 loan for Phase 2 of East Coast Housing Project in 2006 (Linked to Project ID#13307, ID#67502, ID#67504, ID#73590, ID#73591, ID#73592)
description: On August 4, 1997, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed an RMB 50,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8 (97) 1997] for Phase 2 of East Coast Housing Project.  The purpose of this project was to construct 160 housing units in the Roche Caiman district. The loan carried the following terms:  4% interest rate, 8-year maturity, and 3-year grace period. Loan repayments were to be made between 2000 and 2005. Total disbursements through this loan amounted to RMB 49,282,473. Then, on August 29, 2000, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed an agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8A (97) 1997] to reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan (RMB 49,282,473) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 4% interest rate, a 11-year maturity, and a 6-year grace period. The parties also agreed that repayments would be made between 2003 and 2008.    Then, in 2001, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed a second agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8B (18) (97) 1997] to reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan (RMB 49,282,473) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 2% interest rate, a 11-year maturity, and a 6-year grace period.  Then, on December 15, 2003, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed a third agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8C (18) (97) 1997] to reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan (RMB 49,282,473) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 4% interest rate, a 14-year maturity, and a 8-year grace period. The parties also agreed that repayments would be made between 2005 and 2011.   Then, on February 23, 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed a fourth agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8D (18) (97) 1997] to reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan (RMB 49,282,473) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 2% interest rate, a 14-year maturity, and a 10-year grace period. The parties also agreed that repayments would be made in eight, semi-annual installments of RMB 6.2 million ($900,000) between 2008 and 2011. Then, in August 2008, the Government of Seychelles made one principal payment of RMB 683,966 ($100,000) to China Eximbank. However, due to economic difficulties, the Government of Seychelles had difficulty servicing the loan even after the 2000, 2003, 2004, and 2006 reschedulings. Consequently, as of March 2011, principal and interest arrears (worth RMB 55,505,078.32) had accumulated.   Then, on April 18, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed an agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8E (18) 1997] to again reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: 30.5-year maturity (367 months), 20.5-year grace period (247 months), and a 2% interest rate. The parties also agreed that repayments would be made in twenty, semi-annual installments between September 21, 2018 and March 4, 2028. The agreement also stipulated that the borrower could defer payment of an unpaid commitment fee (worth RMB 2,185.04) and unpaid accrued interest (RMB 11,880,770.45) to the first repayment date (September 21, 2018).   This loan rescheduling was part of a larger debt restructuring agreement with China Eximbank that involved two additional loans (captured in Umbrella Project ID#13307). Project ID#73590 captures the 2000 loan rescheduling. Project ID#73591 captures the 2001 loan rescheduling. Project ID#73592 captures the 2003 loan rescheduling. Project ID#73593 captures the 2006 loan rescheduling. Project ID#67504 captures the 2011 loan rescheduling.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 援塞舌尔东海岸住房项目 or 塞舌尔东海岸二期住宅. In the database of Chinese loan commitments to African governments that SAIS-CARI released in 2020, it identifies the loan commitment year for Phase 2 of the East Coast Housing Project as 2007. However, the April 18, 2011 loan rescheduling agreement between China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles clearly indicates that the loan for Phase 2 of the East Coast Housing Project was contracted on August 4, 1997.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank restructures 1997 loan for Phase 2 of East Coast Housing Project in 2006 (Linked to Project ID#13307, ID#67502, ID#67504, ID#73590, ID#73591, ID#73592)

# Description
On August 4, 1997, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed an RMB 50,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8 (97) 1997] for Phase 2 of East Coast Housing Project.  The purpose of this project was to construct 160 housing units in the Roche Caiman district. The loan carried the following terms:  4% interest rate, 8-year maturity, and 3-year grace period. Loan repayments were to be made between 2000 and 2005. Total disbursements through this loan amounted to RMB 49,282,473. Then, on August 29, 2000, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed an agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8A (97) 1997] to reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan (RMB 49,282,473) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 4% interest rate, a 11-year maturity, and a 6-year grace period. The parties also agreed that repayments would be made between 2003 and 2008.    Then, in 2001, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed a second agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8B (18) (97) 1997] to reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan (RMB 49,282,473) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 2% interest rate, a 11-year maturity, and a 6-year grace period.  Then, on December 15, 2003, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed a third agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8C (18) (97) 1997] to reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan (RMB 49,282,473) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 4% interest rate, a 14-year maturity, and a 8-year grace period. The parties also agreed that repayments would be made between 2005 and 2011.   Then, on February 23, 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed a fourth agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8D (18) (97) 1997] to reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan (RMB 49,282,473) would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: a 2% interest rate, a 14-year maturity, and a 10-year grace period. The parties also agreed that repayments would be made in eight, semi-annual installments of RMB 6.2 million ($900,000) between 2008 and 2011. Then, in August 2008, the Government of Seychelles made one principal payment of RMB 683,966 ($100,000) to China Eximbank. However, due to economic difficulties, the Government of Seychelles had difficulty servicing the loan even after the 2000, 2003, 2004, and 2006 reschedulings. Consequently, as of March 2011, principal and interest arrears (worth RMB 55,505,078.32) had accumulated.   Then, on April 18, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Seychelles signed an agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO.8E (18) 1997] to again reschedule the repayment terms of this loan. The parties agreed that the outstanding balance of the loan would be repaid according to the following repayment terms: 30.5-year maturity (367 months), 20.5-year grace period (247 months), and a 2% interest rate. The parties also agreed that repayments would be made in twenty, semi-annual installments between September 21, 2018 and March 4, 2028. The agreement also stipulated that the borrower could defer payment of an unpaid commitment fee (worth RMB 2,185.04) and unpaid accrued interest (RMB 11,880,770.45) to the first repayment date (September 21, 2018).   This loan rescheduling was part of a larger debt restructuring agreement with China Eximbank that involved two additional loans (captured in Umbrella Project ID#13307). Project ID#73590 captures the 2000 loan rescheduling. Project ID#73591 captures the 2001 loan rescheduling. Project ID#73592 captures the 2003 loan rescheduling. Project ID#73593 captures the 2006 loan rescheduling. Project ID#67504 captures the 2011 loan rescheduling.
justification: Project involves loan restructuring and repayment terms without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Multiple loan rescheduling agreements, focus on repayment terms and financial arrangements

title: Chinese Embassy donates office equipment worth USD 7,000 to Seychelles Ministry of Foreign Affairs
description: In February 2006, the Chinese Embassy in Seychelles donated a photocopier and computer worth USD 7,000 to the Seychelles Ministry of Foreign Affairs to facilitate the ministry's work.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates office equipment worth USD 7,000 to Seychelles Ministry of Foreign Affairs

# Description
In February 2006, the Chinese Embassy in Seychelles donated a photocopier and computer worth USD 7,000 to the Seychelles Ministry of Foreign Affairs to facilitate the ministry's work.
justification: Donation of office equipment to government ministry with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Photocopier and computer donation, government sector, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government donates 3,200 tons of maize in 2006
description: In or around 2006, the Chinese Government committed to donating a total of 3,200 tons of maize to the Government of Seychelles. The Government of Seychelles would then sell the maize and use the proceeds to fund an unspecified project. The value of this maize donation is unknown.   300 tons were delivered to the Seychelles Marketing Board (SMB) on February 17, 2006, and another 114 containers were scheduled for delivery by May 2006.
staff_comments: This is separate from a June 2008 donation for 3,500 tons of corn (see Project ID #55719).
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government donates 3,200 tons of maize in 2006

# Description
In or around 2006, the Chinese Government committed to donating a total of 3,200 tons of maize to the Government of Seychelles. The Government of Seychelles would then sell the maize and use the proceeds to fund an unspecified project. The value of this maize donation is unknown.   300 tons were delivered to the Seychelles Marketing Board (SMB) on February 17, 2006, and another 114 containers were scheduled for delivery by May 2006.
justification: Project involves donation of agricultural goods for social development purposes without clear environmental impact
evidence: Maize donation to be sold for funding unspecified project, no direct energy or environmental components

title: Chinese Government provides computer equipment worth SCR 350,000  to National Assembly of Seychelles in January 2006
description: On January 17, 2006, the Chinese Government donated computer equipment worth SCR 350,000 to the National Assembly of Seychelles. The handover ceremony took place during a four-day official visit from Ismail Amat, the Vice Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China.
staff_comments: This project is separate from a 2005 donation of computer equipment worth SCR 800,000 (see Project ID #89360).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides computer equipment worth SCR 350,000  to National Assembly of Seychelles in January 2006

# Description

The handover ceremony took place during a four-day official visit from Ismail Amat, the Vice Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China.
justification: Project involves donation of computer equipment to government institution, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Computer equipment donation to National Assembly of Seychelles, government sector project

title: China Performs Geological and Mineral Resources Survey for Sierra Leone in 2006
description: In 2006, Sierra Leone undertook a comprehensive geological survey of the country's natural resources and developed a comprehensive database of the country's mineral resources. Geological Survey Institute of Henan Province carried out the survey in collaboration with other government agencies between November 21 and December 21 in 2006. The information would be used for future prospecting efforts.   The survey was reportedly was agreed to under a memorandum of understanding signed by President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah in November 2006 during a China-Africa summit in Beijing.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Performs Geological and Mineral Resources Survey for Sierra Leone in 2006

# Description
In 2006, Sierra Leone undertook a comprehensive geological survey of the country's natural resources and developed a comprehensive database of the country's mineral resources. Geological Survey Institute of Henan Province carried out the survey in collaboration with other government agencies between November 21 and December 21 in 2006. The information would be used for future prospecting efforts.   The survey was reportedly was agreed to under a memorandum of understanding signed by President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah in November 2006 during a China-Africa summit in Beijing.
justification: Geological survey for mineral resources without specific focus on energy transition minerals or fossil fuels
evidence: Comprehensive geological survey, mineral resources database development, no specific mineral types mentioned

title: China Provides Training on Mechanical Cultivation System to Sierra Leone in 2006
description: In February 2006, Sierra Leone implemented a food security program under the Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security. Dr. Sam Mondeh of the Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security presented farmers with equipment, including 136 tractors, for them to develop a mechanized farming system to maximize agricultural yield. The tractors were donated by Iran, Libya, and China to provincial towns of Kambia, Port Loko, Moyamba, Matru Jong, Bo, Pujehun, Kenema, Kailahun, Koinadugu, Bombali, and Kono.   Additionally, Chinese technicians trained 60 people from Sierra Leone on mechanical cultivation system. Two trainers have arrived to prepare tractors and have donated 69 tractors and 8 combined harvesters.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China Provides Training on Mechanical Cultivation System to Sierra Leone in 2006

# Description
In February 2006, Sierra Leone implemented a food security program under the Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security. Dr. Sam Mondeh of the Ministry of Agriculture and Food Security presented farmers with equipment, including 136 tractors, for them to develop a mechanized farming system to maximize agricultural yield. The tractors were donated by Iran, Libya, and China to provincial towns of Kambia, Port Loko, Moyamba, Matru Jong, Bo, Pujehun, Kenema, Kailahun, Koinadugu, Bombali, and Kono.   Additionally, Chinese technicians trained 60 people from Sierra Leone on mechanical cultivation system. Two trainers have arrived to prepare tractors and have donated 69 tractors and 8 combined harvesters.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural development and training, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Training on mechanical cultivation system, donation of agricultural equipment (tractors and harvesters), focus on food security and agricultural yield improvement

title: China Donates Agricultural Equipment to Sierra Leone
description: In 2006, three Chinese expatriates assembled 16 tractors and eight combined harvesters at Kissy mechanical workshop as a move to boost the food security initiative in Sierra Leone. Hawanatu Conteh urged the Dr Sama Monde, Minister of Agriculture and Food Security, to initiate the recruitment of 20 technicians from his ministry to participate in the process of training, assembling, and operating the tractors. On March 27, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to Sierra Leone, Cheng Wenju, handed over a large consignment of tractors, combined harvesters, and other agricultural machinery to the government of Sierra Leone at a ceremony held at the Youyi Building in Freetown. All of the tractors included in the donation were installed and tested by Chinese technical team.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
China Donates Agricultural Equipment to Sierra Leone

# Description
In 2006, three Chinese expatriates assembled 16 tractors and eight combined harvesters at Kissy mechanical workshop as a move to boost the food security initiative in Sierra Leone. Hawanatu Conteh urged the Dr Sama Monde, Minister of Agriculture and Food Security, to initiate the recruitment of 20 technicians from his ministry to participate in the process of training, assembling, and operating the tractors. On March 27, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to Sierra Leone, Cheng Wenju, handed over a large consignment of tractors, combined harvesters, and other agricultural machinery to the government of Sierra Leone at a ceremony held at the Youyi Building in Freetown. All of the tractors included in the donation were installed and tested by Chinese technical team.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural development and food security without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of agricultural equipment (tractors, harvesters), focus on food security initiative

title: China donates Office Supplies to Sierra Leone
description: On August 15, 2006, a handover ceremony of the Chinese government's donation of office supplies was held at the Sierra Leone Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The aid package included computers, fax machines, copiers, laser printers, and split air conditioning. Contacts for this project are Chinese Ambassador Cheng Wenjuand the Sierra Leone Vice Foreign Minister Kamal. The commitment date and financial amount for this project are unknown.
combined_text:

# Description
On August 15, 2006, a handover ceremony of the Chinese government's donation of office supplies was held at the Sierra Leone Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Contacts for this project are Chinese Ambassador Cheng Wenjuand the Sierra Leone Vice Foreign Minister Kamal. The commitment date and financial amount for this project are unknown.
justification: Project involves donation of office supplies without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of computers, fax machines, copiers, printers, and air conditioning units to government ministry

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Sierra-Pasto Elementary School Construction Project
description: On January 26, 2007, the Chinese embassy in Sierra Leone held the opening ceremony for the Sierra-Pasto Elementary School in Freetown, whose previous name was Pasto Primary School. The value of this project is unknown.
combined_text:

EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Sierra-Pasto Elementary School Construction Project

# Description

justification: Project is focused on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Elementary school construction, education sector focus

title: Hunan provincial government donates medical equipment to Sierra Leone
description: In November 2006, the government in Hunan Province, China, committed to donate a set of medical equipments to Sierra Leone when Sierra Leone's President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah visited Hunan Province during the Beijing Summit of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum. In mid-August 2007, the equipments were delivered to Freetown, including 6 devices including X-ray machines, electrocardiographs, and digital ultrasonic diagnostic instruments. The medical equipments worth RMB 550,000.   On September 5, 2007, the Chinese embassy held a handover ceremony for the donation of medical equipment from the Government of Hunan Province to the Government of Sierra Leone. Chinese Ambassador to Serbia Cheng Wenju, Political Counselor Wang Haitao, Business Counsellor Zhao Zhongqiu, Serbian President Kaba, Minister of Health Thomas, and local news media attended the handover ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Hunan provincial government donates medical equipment to Sierra Leone

# Description
In November 2006, the government in Hunan Province, China, committed to donate a set of medical equipments to Sierra Leone when Sierra Leone's President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah visited Hunan Province during the Beijing Summit of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum. In mid-August 2007, the equipments were delivered to Freetown, including 6 devices including X-ray machines, electrocardiographs, and digital ultrasonic diagnostic instruments. The medical equipments worth RMB 550,000.   On September 5, 2007, the Chinese embassy held a handover ceremony for the donation of medical equipment from the Government of Hunan Province to the Government of Sierra Leone. Chinese Ambassador to Serbia Cheng Wenju, Political Counselor Wang Haitao, Business Counsellor Zhao Zhongqiu, Serbian President Kaba, Minister of Health Thomas, and local news media attended the handover ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of medical equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical equipment donation including X-ray machines, electrocardiographs, and digital ultrasonic diagnostic instruments
